and repeat from * to * to 2 sts before eor brk with c1 being careful to get the c1 yarn from under the c2 yarn brp with c2 yo with c1 only explanation of abbreviations for one-pass brioche brk knit the stitch and its corresponding yo if it exists as if they were one stitch with c1 getting the c1 strand from underneath the c2 strand brp bring both strands of yarn to the front then purl the stitch and its corresponding yo if it exists as if they were one stitch with c2 only here s a tutorial for you https // www youtube com/watch ladderback jacquard v=dmo0t1dfrrg the ladderback jacquard technique manages colourwork in knitting it handles floats the long yarn strands are carried across the back of your work when using multiple colours this technique makes neat professional-looking colourwork it avoids floats getting caught or creating bulky sections on the back it creates a second inner layer to your sock to achieve that it requires additional stitches the pattern refers to them as lb stitches these stitches are not seen from the out- side in the finished sock however when knitting you might still see them in the first few row below to distinguish lb stitches from the ones we can see on the out- side this pattern refers to the visible stitches as regular stitches 3 ladderback jacquard continued set-up in the first row the additional stitches will have to be created so whenev- er asked to create an lb stitch do a backward loop with the given colour s the oth- er coloured strand s will lay in front of this backward loop their little strand will later cover up the new stitch actual technique whenever you reach an lb stitch purl it with the indicated colour s keep the other strand s to the front so it hides behind their strand s ladderback jacquard with two colours usually we work colourwork with two colours on- ly it means that at each lb stitch it will be the opposite colour of your current knitting sometimes lb stitches are also between
